4.3. Hirshfeld Surface Analysis of the azo–BTA Star Crystal
To more closely examine the intermolecular interactions in the crystals of azo-stars experimentally
]. This method has been successfully utilized to characterize aminoazobenzene
], to investigate the intermolecular interactions in azobenzenes revealing photoinduced
], and to explain the molecular origin of the color changes of guest signaling
The Hirshfeld surface is a three-dimensional isosurface effectively determining the volume of the
molecule in the crystal. The surface itself is deﬁned so that for each point on this surface, one-half of
the electron density is due to the spherically averaged noninteracting atoms comprising the molecule,
and the other half is due to those comprising the rest of the crystal [
(normalized contact distance), which is the negative or positive sumof
when the contacts are shorter or longer than the sum of the van der Waals radii of the interacting
